message: What is your startup about? I'm interested :)
I tried giving away free stickers with pictures of animals on them but no one is interested in either stickers or animals. Any other suggestions? I'm stumped.
Get where your users are. Find users that will talk about your product and help them talk about it.
Definitely agreed about finding users that want to talk about it, and help them.
In my experience, you know pretty much right away whether or not you

Try to figure out a way for your users to benefit from telling a friend (i.e. the first person with a fax machine really wanted other people to get a fax machine).  Also, tell a good story.  Some startups are naturally worth talking about.  If yours isn't, figure out a good story (Zappos sold shoes, 37s sells project management software-- yet people talk about them ALL THE TIME)
People aren't interested in stickers or free stuff.  They just want something that will solve their problem that's easy to use and understand.
have built something that's gonna take off based on how quickly people "get it" and use it.

@jonnii is there any thing you are doing as part of your startup that could become a source of revenue? For example, a photographer starting her practice could also offer workshops where she shares her expertise with other just starting photographers.
People have to realize why they need your product, you can only do so much.

people are completly wrong about techcrunch they think that getting coverage there will make any diffeerence for your startup. convore is a good product and thats the ONLY reason they are getting traction. I am talking this way because i was in the middle of building something like convore and was about to launch it until i saw this so changing my strategy a bit. there is a huge opportunity around groups and convore did the best job until now, i wish them luck

I much rather a sticker made up of many people, than constantly having to keep them tied up in my basement.
Stickers are so 2010.  Temporary tattoos are where its at.

My company is building life sized animal stickers made from real animals. For example we have stickers of horses for when you can't afford a horse, but you want a horse. The reason for the sticker format is so that the horse cannot run away.

Legwork + good product + animal stickers.

I think there are a bunch of hacks you can do, contact smaller name bloggers who are trying to make a name for themselves, start being active in the community surrounding your product, go around to events related to your product, etc.
@yoshofosho You sign up for groups that interest you, and then you have conversations about topics that are cool
@Jester5093 there is now: http://canv.as
So, does anyone have any unique ideas related to this topic?
It's all about legwork IMO
There's also a lot to be said for contacting night and weekend bloggers - hit 'em when the news is slow, and you're a lot more likely to get their attention.
@jolieodell The user acquisition strategy has to be baked into the core of the product, you can't just 'slap on the marketing' once it's done.
@jolieodell That said, this guide is a pretty good checklist for once your product is already really good.

let it mature if it works the ones for whom it work will let others know
Bacon, everyone loves bacon. Just give out crispy bacon with your stickers. Make signs of bacon, bacon newspaper ads, bacon web banners, bacon!

On another (non bacon related) note, I started a skateboarding company a year ago and my first move was to produce stickers. I made 1500 large high quality stickers and gave them out for free. I later closed the company due to a lack of interest in the skateboard industry. To this day random people come up to me and recognize me and my company because of my stickers. It's amazing how well sticker advertising can work if you have 1000+ spread out randomly in areas where your demographic is most likely to see them. Stickers are a long term payoff, for the mean time work on building a loyal community.
I wouldn't try and get users with TC coverage unless you're targeting other startups.
@davidwparker only founders, VCs, etc read techcrunch. "users" don't care
